intro: Lappa conglomerata, commonly known as the clustered bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its clusters of bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and can reach heights of up to 60 centimeters. Lappa conglomerata is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its striking floral display.
